Award.AwardTitle: SI2-CHE: CCP-SAS - Collaborative Computing consortium for advanced analyses of structural data in chemical biology and soft condensed matter
Award.AbstractNarration:
An international team consisting of Paul Butler (University of Tennessee, Knoxville and NIST), Jianhan Chen (Kansas State University), Emre Brooks (University of Texas Health Science Center, San Antonio) and their UK collaborators led by Stephen J. Perkins (University College, London) are supported through the SI2-CHE program. The object of this project is to provide a web-based GUI front-end with a high-performance back-end to increase the accessibility of advanced atomistic modeling of scattering data by novice users. Advanced analysis modules and new simulation methods including implicit solvent models are being developed to increase the accuracy of scattering calculations and simulation protocols. Software is being developed and disseminated with continual feedback from the research teams' large international user-base. These efforts leverage an international user and developer community that use high-performance computing resources on a wide-range of cutting-edge chemical problems.

A typical bench scientist purifies and characterizes samples, collects the small angle x-ray scattering (SAXS), small angle neutron scattering (SANS), or analytical ultracentrifugation (AUC) data, and interprets the results using simplistic models. It is rare that the same individual also has the skills to use advanced atomistic simulation software. The CCP-SAS project is focused on developing an easy-to-use modeling package that enables users to generate physically accurate atomistic models, calculate scattering profiles and compare results to experimental scattering data sets in a single web-based software suite. This enables a broad range of scattering scientists to access often complicated simulation and scattering analysis methods seamlessly thus providing a significant acceleration to the discovery process.

The US based investigators are supported by the CHE and ACI divisions within NSF; the UK based investigators are supported by the EPSRC.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major infrastructural investment by the US and UK in high brilliance multiuser X- ray synchrotrons and neutron sources during the last two decades has been immensely successful in allowing external (university and commercial) users to exploit these facilities for data collection on ever more challenging and important systems, particularly in chemical biology and soft condensed matter. To realize the full benefit of the instrumental investment for novel engineering and material science applications requires integrating the plethora of X-ray and neutron data with user-friendly, high-throughput, molecular modeling of the data, in order to reveal how structure in these systems changes in time and space with varying experimental conditions.

 

This project is part of a large US-UK collaboration that was motivated by the recognized importance of structural modeling at the large multiuser synchrotron and neutron facilities in both countries. The overall objective is to develop a CCP-SAS framework (http://www.ccpsas.org) that provides a user friendly interface for integrating data obtained from complementary disciplines such as small angle X-ray and neutron scattering (SAXS and SANS), analytical ultracentrifugation (AUC) and nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (NMR) to generate detailed, highly physical conformational ensembles for broad range of systems in biology and soft condensed matter science. The specific objective of the University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio (UTHSCSA) subproject was to take existing and new software tools and produce a website allowing researchers to conveniently access the tools in a uniform way. This relieves researchers from having to install often complex software and updates, provides a uniform look and feel, gives researchers seamless access to large computer clusters, and makes it easier for scientist software developers to provide new capabilities.  To this end, we developed the GenApp framework (https://genapp.rocks) which simplifies and automates the process of building a website or science gateway.  GenApp was successfully used to build the SASSIE-web gateway and multiple other sites for SAXS, SANS and other dicisplines. Efforts supported by this award have led to 12 peer-reviewed publications (despite the very modest budget of ~$263K total cost).

 

The GenApp framework is now publicly available and available to the research community. The CCP-SAS software generated by GenApp has been utilized by hundreds of users since its launch and become one of the premier tools in molecular modeling of scattering data. The software environment has enabled multidisciplinary experimental teams to gain a detailed understanding of complex chemical interactions and how they shape structural organization. The PI, his collaborators and the research team have organized multiple workshops and training sessions on CCP-SAS during the project period. Multiple undergraduate and graduate students and postdocs have been involved in this project and received valuable training in this multidisciplinary project. The work on the GenApp framework continues to be advanced with a new NSF funding awards from the NSF’s Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure  (Award numbers 1739549 and 1740097).
